content.description:
Toddler is a very easy fists-to-offwidth crack boulder. It's a great introduction to this size for

absolute

beginners.
content.location:
Toddler is on the west side of the same boulder as

Ladyfingers.

content.description: Climb the face without using the left crack or arete on the right. Start low, and standing. The crux is pulling on and sticking the first move or 2, but the climbing keeps up, and then a big move into the horizontal crack/ledge up high and right.
content.protection: It has a pretty flat landing - don't blow the throw move though!
content.location:
It is immediately right of the

Toddler

crack if you are facing it.

content.description:
Lady Fingers climbs a finger crack up the south face of a large boulder near the summit of South Green Mountain. The crack varies from wide fingers to difficult-to-utilize seams. The climb is on a steep, 80 degrees slab and the face itself lacks holds better than pebbles, so having some finger crack technique can be very helpful.

The first ascent (and original name) is currently unknown, but it's an obvious crack in a well-traveled area, so who knows?
content.protection: It's a high-enough boulder to consider what would happen if you peel off and the slabby nature makes things a little more complicated. There's an OK but not GREAT landing. The crack could accept small gear (theoretically), but it's suggested to go into the climb as a solo and commit. It's a long way to bring up a bouldering pad. A buddy at the bottom spotting you is your best bet.
content.location: Lady Fingers is on a boulder east of East Green Mountain along the prominent south east ridge of Green Mountain.
